pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.2: At that time Venerable Pilindavaccha wanted to build a shelter, and he was having a hillside cleared near Rājagaha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.3: On that occasion King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha went to Pilindavaccha,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.4: bowed down to him, sat down to one side,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.7: “I’m clearing the hillside, great king, because I want to build a shelter.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.10: “Well then, Venerable, please ask the Master and tell me the outcome.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.12: And Pilindavaccha instructed, inspired, and gladdened King Bimbisāra with a teaching.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.13: The king rose from his seat, bowed down to Pilindavaccha, circumambulated him with his right side towards him, and departed.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.14: Soon afterwards Pilindavaccha sent a message to the Master:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.15: “Venerable Sir, King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha wishes to provide a monastery worker.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.17: The Master then gave a teaching and addressed the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.19: Once again King Bimbisāra went to Pilindavaccha,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.20: bowed down to him, and sat down to one side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.22: “Venerable, has the Master allowed monastery workers?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.24: “Well then, I’ll provide you with a monastery worker.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.25: But after promising a monastery worker to Pilindavaccha, he forgot about it. He only remembered after a long time. He then addressed the official in charge of all practical affairs,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.26: “Listen, has the monastery worker I promised been provided?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.28: “How long is it since we made that promise?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.29: The official counted the days and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.31: “Well then, provide him with five hundred monastery workers.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.33: The official provided Pilindavaccha with five hundred monastery workers, and a separate village was established.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.34: They called it “The Monastery Workers’ Village” and “Pilinda Village.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.1: And Pilindavaccha began associating with the families in that village.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.2: After robing up one morning, he took his bowl and robe and entered Pilinda Village for almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.3: At that time they were holding a festival in that village,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.4: and the children were dressed up with ornaments and garlands.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.5: As Pilindavaccha was walking on continuous almsround, he came to the house of a certain monastery worker,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.6: where he sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.7: Just then the daughter of the house had seen other children dressed up in ornaments and garlands. She was crying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.14: “How can poor people like us afford garlands and ornaments?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.15: Pilindavaccha took a roll of grass and said to the mother,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.16: “Here, place this roll of grass on the girl’s head.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.18: and it turned into a beautiful golden garland.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.19: Even the royal compound had nothing like it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.21: “Sir, in the house of a particular monastery worker there’s a beautiful golden garland.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.22: Even your household, sir, has nothing like it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.23: So how did those poor people get it?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.24: No doubt it was taken by theft.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.25: And King Bimbisāra had that family imprisoned.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.26: Once again Pilindavaccha robed up in the morning, took his bowl and robe, and entered Pilinda Village for almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.27: As he was walking on continuous almsround, he came to the house of that monastery worker.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.29: “Where has the family of this monastery worker gone?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.30: “Venerable, the king had them imprisoned because of that golden garland.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.1: Pilindavaccha then went to King Bimbisāra’s house
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.2: and sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.4: bowed down to him, and sat down to one side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.6: “Great king, why have you had the family of that monastery worker imprisoned?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.7: “Venerable, in the house of that monastery worker there was a beautiful golden garland.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.8: Even the royal compound has nothing like it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.9: So how did those poor people get it?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.10: No doubt it was taken by theft.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.11: Pilindavaccha then focused his mind on turning King Bimbisāra’s stilt house into gold.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.13: And he said, “Great king, how did you get so much gold?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.14: “Understood, Venerable, this is your supernormal power.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.17: “It seems Venerable Pilindavaccha has shown a superhuman ability, a wonder of supernormal power, to the king and his court!”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.18: They were delighted and gained confidence in Pilindavaccha, and they brought him the five kinds of tonic:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.19: ghee, butter, oil, honey, and sugar.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.20: Ordinarily, too, Pilindavaccha was getting these five tonics.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.21: Since he was getting so much, he gave it away to his followers.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.22: And his followers acquired an abundance of tonics.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.23: After filling up jars and pitchers and setting these aside, they filled their water filters and bags and hung these in the windows.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.24: The tonics were dripping all over,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.25: and the dwellings became infested with rats.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.26: People who were walking about the dwellings saw this, and they grumbled and complained,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.27: “These Sakyan ascetics are hoarding goods indoors, just like King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.28: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.29: and the monks of few desires …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.31: “How can these monks choose to live in such abundance?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.32: After criticizing those monks in many ways, they told the Master. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.33: “Is it true, monks, that some monks are living like this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.36: How can those foolish men choose to live in such abundance?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.37: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.38: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.39: ‘After being received, the tonics allowable for sick monks—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.40: that is, ghee, butter, oil, honey, and sugar—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.41: should be used from storage for at most seven days.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.42: If one uses them beyond that, one commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.1: The tonics allowable for sick monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.3: ghee from cows, ghee from goats, ghee from buffaloes, or ghee from whatever animal whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.7: sesame oil, mustard seed oil, honey tree oil, castor oil, oil from tallow.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.12: After being received […] should be used from storage for at most seven days:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.13: they are to be used for seven days at the maximum.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.14: If one uses them beyond that, one commits an offense entailing relinquishment:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.15: it becomes subject to relinquishment at dawn on the eighth day.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.16: The tonics should be relinquished to an Order, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.17: “And, monks, they should be relinquished in this way: …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.18: To be expanded as in [Relinquishment 1, paragraphs 13–17](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1#13), with appropriate substitutions.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.19: ‘Venerables, these tonics that I have kept over seven days are to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.20: I relinquish them to the Order.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.23: ‘I give these tonics back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.24: If it is more than seven days and he perceives it as more than seven days, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.25: If it is more than seven days, but he is unsure if it is, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.26: If it is more than seven days, but he perceives it as less than seven days, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.27: If they have not been determined, but he perceives them as determined, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.28: If they have not been given away, but he perceives them as given away, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.29: If they have not been lost, but he perceives them as lost, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.30: If they have not been destroyed, but he perceives them as destroyed, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.31: If they have not been burnt, but he perceives them as burnt, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.32: If they have not been stolen, but he perceives them as stolen, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.33: After the relinquished tonics have been returned, they are not to be used on the body, nor are they to be eaten.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.34: They can used in lamps or as a black coloring agent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.35: Other monks may use them on the body, but they may not eat them.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.36: If it is less than seven days, but he perceives it as more than seven days, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.37: If it is less than seven days, but he is unsure if it is, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.38: If it is less than seven days and he perceives it as less than seven days, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.40: if within seven days they have been determined, given away, lost, destroyed, burnt, stolen, or taken on trust;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.41: if, without any desire for them, he gives them up to a person who is not fully ordained, and he then obtains them again and then uses them;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.43: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.44: The third rule, the training rule on tonics, is finished.
